entry.title: Raspberry PI
entry.content:
This post describes the Raspberry PI.

Hardware

Raspberry PI 3

  • SOC (System on chip): Broadcom BCM2837
  • CPU: 4 Ã— ARM Cortex-A53 @ 1.2GHz (ARMv8-A 64 bits)
  • GPU: VideoCore IV @ 400 MHz
  • RAM: 1GB LPDDR2 (900 MHz)
  • Wifi: 2.4GHz 802.11n

GPIO pinout

GPIO libraries

There are libraries for each language (Go, Node, Python, ...) for accessing GPIO-pins on the Raspberry Pi but these librairies don't have the same features. So you should choose a programming language according to needed features.

RPi.GPIO Go-RPIO rpi-gpio
Language Python Golang NodeJS
Pull up/down/off YES YES NO
Event callback YES NO YES

entry.title: Cloud Storage
entry.summary: Cloud Storage is a model of data storage more flexible than traditional solution like NAS and SAN. Each cloud provider offers a proprietary solution of Cloud Storage. However, There are some self-hosted object storage solutions...
entry.content:
Cloud Storage is a model of data storage more flexible than traditional solution like NAS and SAN. Each cloud provider offers a proprietary solution of Cloud Storage. However, There are some self-hosted object storage solutions...

Object Storage

  • Swift: cloud storage solution for OpenStack by RedHat
  • Ceph : REST interface that's compatible with applications written for S3 and Swift.
  • Minio: written in the Go language, Minio is an open source object storage server with Amazon S3 compatible API.
  • Rook: Based on Ceph, Rook is designed to run as a native Kubernetes service.
  • Gluster: best choice for large, immutable files and less suitable for oft-accessed smaller-sized files

entry.title: Websphere Application Server
entry.summary: Websphere Application Server is a middleware from IBM that hosts Java based web applications.
entry.content:
Websphere Application Server is a middleware from IBM that hosts Java based web applications.

Websphere Application Server

There are seven WAS editions in the market.

  • Liberty Core (free and Open Source)
  • Express
  • Base
  • Network Deployment
  • Hypervisor Edition
  • z/OS
  • Developers

Below, an illustration of installation of WAS Network Deployment:

RMI/IIOP

Java RMI/IIOP (Remote Method Invocation over Internet Inter-ORB Protocol) is part of the Java 2 Platform. This is a protocol similar to RPC (Remote Procedure Call) often used with EJB (Enterprise Java Bean) and WAS (Websphere Application Server).

This protocol is quite complex and it is difficult to find relevant and synthetic information. So, it's time to write a quick post just before I forget everything.

  • Flow #1: is only required in WAS Network Deployment clustered instance to find the Bootstrap server. DCS is part of High Availability Manager and/or Work Load Manager.
  • Flow #2: first locate request to the ORB Bootstrap port
  • Flow #3: second locate request to the ORB listener port

For more information : Understanding how EJB calls operate in WebSphere Application Server V6.1

entry.title: Information security dictionary
entry.summary: This post is a simple dictionary for information security vocabulary and acronym.
entry.content:
This post is a simple dictionary for information security vocabulary and acronym.

Authentication

  • Handle: pseudonye
  • Password complexity requirements

Attack

  • Pastjacking: using malicious javascript to insert sneaky text into pasted terminal commands

PKI and Certificate

  • CRL (Certificate Revocation List)
  • CSR (Certificate Signing Request)
  • CTL (Certificate Trusted List)

Malware

  • CC or C2 (Command & Control)
  • PUA (Potentially Unwanted Application)
